case_vignette: a man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years. he notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement. examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting. there were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing an itchy and burning rash on my legs that recurs every winter.
How long has this been occurring, and does it improve during warmer months?
This has been occurring for the past 3 years and it recurs every winter.
Do you notice any changes in the rash after exposure to hot baths or showers?
The information about how my rash reacts to hot baths or showers wasn't provided.
Have you been diagnosed with any skin conditions or allergies in the past?
No, I have no known history of atopy or allergies.
Does the rash manifest as dry, scaly patches, or do you observe any swelling or blisters?
The rash has ovoid, erythematous plaques with variable scaling and some areas have focal weeping and crusting.
Have any members of your family had similar skin issues or any known skin diseases?
The information about my family history regarding similar skin issues or any known skin diseases wasn't provided.
Is the rash localized only on your legs or does it appear elsewhere on your body?
The rash is on my lower legs and dorsal feet, and the rest of my skin is notably dry but without rashes.
Final Diagnosis: Eczema Craquelé (Asteatotic Eczema)

trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Winter eczema (also known as asteatotic eczema)

The rash recurs every winter, and it hasn't improved with hydrocortisone cream that I tried using.
